messages.message:
I had uploaded four files to the Converse, and now I want to exclude one of them from a query I’m running.
By default all four are added to the context now, and I could not figure out how to remove one. I accidentally deleted one thinking the garbage bin icon would remove it from the context and not from the whole conversation.

Finally I’ve found a roundabout way of doing “Limit message scope” to one file, and only then add the other two.
Curiously then the “remove from scope” button appears, which I wanted there in the first place.

Can we always have this option to quickly mark what’s in scope? Or maybe be able to drag between “Message scope” and “Other files” sections?
Helpful feedback! We're actively looking to make this more intuitive. cc: @alagu @Natasha
@Sławek Biel you should also be able to shift select files and then click the “limit scope to selected files” button at the top

Oh, this is helpful, I had not discovered that.
However I don’t entirely get what it does, when I shift+click two files it highlights all the files in between too. Can I only select a single consecutive block?
You can also use ctrl (or cmd) click to select individual files
Hmm, this didn’t work either. Only added a single file
Do you see the bulk button at the top when you have those files selected? The one you’re clicking is still for a single file
Btw, it’s great to see how you’re actually interacting with this! Great feedback
Aha! Found the button and it did what I wanted. Maybe I’m just bad at discovering UI interactions

I agree with the suggestions, it would be more intuitive if we -
• Always display Message scope title
• Remove the `Limit message scope` from the individual files in the list, and just keep it a toggle for + or - from scope for that file.

I do think we should also keep in mind how users who aren't developers like Slawek are using this. It sounds like research has found that it's much more likely for users to want to narrow the scope to one document than all but one documents. I think there's a design sync this week to figure this stuff out.
I know some people have been advocating for a design that's much different than this even, so we'll see what comes out of it!

Makes sense. The main reason I feel this is confusing is because toggling and limiting are different actions which isn't separated enough in the current design.
Currently it replaces toggle icon button with a limit action when all files are in scope. It'd be better if it's separated by instead either having a separate icon button for limiting, or having the limit action at the top and the context menu. Let's discuss this more in the sync
